Comment: Fun maths based puzzle with clear description and appropriate difficulty. Good range of test and validators and found no issues with any them.

Took me a while to code a solution but only because I didn't read the full statement and couldn't work out what was wrong with having the date 0464-84-47...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: already approved

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Already accepted see previous comment !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Very nice one.


The specification should explain the date completion with a left sided zero when needed (like year 0831 below) 

I do not understand why Validator 4:  expects "".

input is 83107110. Two dates comply. This is not suppose to happen.
the date 0831-07-10 complies: 
    - 0831-07-10 => 8310710 => 831071*10 => 83107110
the date 0889-01-30 complies: 
    - 0889-01-30 => 08890130 => 83*107110 => 83107110

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: A very cool and original puzzle that looks easier than it actually is! My first approach didn't work, and if I hadn't read Kayou's comment and EnamSon's response, I think it would have taken me a while to find a solution.
Anyway, well done!

# Dear problem creator,

# Thank you for designing such a clever and engaging puzzle. This challenge 
# beautifully combines number theory (factorization) and date validation, 
# wrapped in a real-world narrative context.

# The idea of encoding a date into a product of two closest factors and then 
# reversing that through careful parsing is both original and intellectually satisfying.

# This solution carefully respects the constraints:
# - It checks all possible ways to split the mysterious number into two integers (a and b).
# - It verifies that their product forms a valid date.
# - Most importantly, it ensures (a, b) is the closest factor pair of the product,
#   maintaining the integrity of the puzzle's logic.

# This approach ensures the solution is both accurate and optimized for performance.

# Once again, kudos for creating such a fun and brain-teasing problem!

I don't know if I miss something or if  validator 4 and 6 have an issue.:

For validator 4 ; I found 2 dates and choose the date with min difference B-A, but i got it wrong.
input : 200104091
A          B                abs(A-B)   date
4091, 20010         15919,        '8186-09-10'
1        20010409    20010408  '2001-04-09'

I have the same issue with validator 6.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is a nice puzzle... at first i thought the puzzle could had the difficult of a clash of code, but it took me a lot of time to code a solution... the factorization to create a unique solution is a good idea and there are test cases where if you don't use the factorization it doesn't works, i like that
ooh... i thought the N was between - 10^5 < N < 10^10... but the ( - ) is not part of the inequation
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Goal
* Please format "a" and "b" (in | a - b |) as [[variables]].

* Please remove the quotation marks around "01", "12" and "31".

Difficulty
* Can be changed to Easy. I can just try all possible ways of splitting the mysterious numbers and see which ones lead to a valid date. In many cases, there is only one valid date, so I don't have to perform any factorisation to check which of the valid dates is the final answer.

Constraints
* Please format "N" as a [[variable]].

Cases
* Please swap around the cases so that those requiring the same output is grouped as a pair:
   â€¢ 2078-12-08
   â€¢ 0127-01-20
   â€¢ 0831-07-10

Thanks.

Thank you, I hadn't noticed that this exercise could be solved with a simple brute-force approach. I appreciate you taking the time to check everything.

I have made all the updates you suggested.
It's probably better for the author to change the dash to a bullet point.

Hello ManuelJ,
My contribution wasn't accecpted in the time and your approval has expired. Perhaps, you could re-approval it, please
4091 * 20010 = 81860910 but 8182 and 10005 are the closest factors of 81860910, not 4091 and 20010

Hi FannyWise,
I canâ€™t begin to tell you how much your comment filled me with joy and encouraged me to keep walking the winding path of creativity and originality.
Itâ€™s so rare for a problem creator to receive such sincere and uplifting feedback.
From the bottom of my heart, thank you! ðŸ’™

Hello FredericLocquet,
My contribution wasn't accecpted in the time and your approval has expired. Perhaps, you could re-approval it, please

Thanks.

The date format already indicates that the string should be completed with zeros if necessary.

The valid factorisation of 08890130 is 830 * 10711 not 83 * 1070110.

Suggested changes:
new Validator 4:
10124123 => 0124-12-30

new Validator 6:
61284579 => 2806-01-12

old Validator 4 becomes new Test 8:
83107110 => 0831-07-10

new Validator 8:
12506310 => 0125-06-30

old Validator 6 becomes new Test 9:
200104091 => 2001-04-09

new Validator 9:
100309071 => 1003-09-07

Do they look good to you? @EnamSon

Hi 5DN1L,
Thank you for your involvement in my contribution. I think a puzzle doesn't need to be solved immediately, and we could spend a few days seeing how it evolves. Don't you agree?

Thank you for your reply.

I'm a bit worried when two players mentioned that Validator 4 and Validator 6 gave them issues. It's an indicator of tests likely not having adequate case coverage.

I'd highly recommend to make the changes, especially if case coverage is found to be an issue. For now, I respect your choice and we can indeed wait a bit more.
ok, if another player mentions that these validators gave them issues, you can make this change
Noted, and thank you for your understanding! ðŸ™‚
Thank you too

Hi 5DN1L,
Can you make this change ?
Done!
Players don't like my puzzle. Perhaps, it will be necessary to archive it.

The rating is a bit low at the momentâ€¦

I guess it would have helped if a bit more illustration was given for "closest factorization", i.e. why "The closest factorization is 20781208 = 4471 Ã— 4648", by given other pairs of factors which are not as close. This seems to be part that confuses players the most.
I modified the statement of the contribution. If you are agree, you can apply it on the puzzle.
Actually, you're still able to modify a puzzle (like you just did now) even after it's approved. It doesn't have to be applied by me ðŸ˜‰
uhh, i didn't know that
Ok! Found MY bug :-) All checked! If i could I would approve.
I got it now. I din't think to check the factorization of the date.
It's done :-)
